Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story: I glance at my inbox and see a new message from a teammate. The subject line is low-key, and the body says, “No action needed, just FYI.” Still, as a colleague, I know there’s an unspoken expectation to acknowledge messages quickly, to show I’m present and engaged. But my mind is already tangled in the technical details of a new feature. The design documents are due tomorrow, and the product and QA teams are waiting for my input before they can move forward. I promised them I’d have my part ready by the end of the day. My fingers hover over the keyboard, torn between dashing off a polite reply to the email and diving back into the code and diagrams. I feel the pressure mounting—if I pause to respond, I lose my train of thought on the design; if I ignore the message, I risk seeming unresponsive. The clock ticks, and I sit there, wrestling with which expectation to meet first.
